reviews.review_msg: Lectures are dry with a lot of material. Slides are pretty boring and unorganized. When Charles is lecturing he's kind of all over the place, but he's very knowledgable and decent at explaining concepts. Often, he didn't get through all of the slides because of repeating himself so much and hyper-focusing on random topics. Exams are kinda tough.
His lectures were extremely boring and dry. Absolutely no interactivity. Imagine you are listening to the world's most boring podcast and the exam is on the smallest detail.

Charles clearly cares about his students, but asks a little too much from us. 446 used a lot of 306 material, as well as genetics (which is not a prereq for the course). The slides were horribly disorganized with too many figures. Midterms were fair but difficult, and two essays were due only 3 days after the 2nd midterm. Would not recommend.

446 is essentially 306 part 2 & just as heavy on the electrophys. 3hrs of lecture though on myschedule its listed as 2hrs, and then adds up to 30mins more if he feels like it. Assigned 2 4-6 page papers both due 3 days after the midterm. Tests are tight for time with no MC. Material is interesting but these facts make the class suffocating.

His exams are very difficult to predict and require you to extend your knowledge. Even after studying daily and keeping up with the material, I felt the final was rough. But overall, he seems like a really nice guy and he is there to help you.

Course material is not hard, but it doesn't matter because that's not what is on the exams. Exams are riddled with typos and ask irrelevant questions (e.g. 7/20 points on the 306 midterm went to biomechanical questions). Will tell you some material won't be on exams and yet he'll test it anyway. Used 3 textbooks (costly!), and all were examinable.

Dr. Krieger is amazingly sweet and patient. Lectures move incredibly fast and I felt a little knocked over after some of them at the sheer amount of material covered that is NOT given on the slides. However, his exams are totally fair and he is more than happy to answer any questions. Written essays are marked pretty tough, no one got perfect.
Amazing prof and equally amazing person. Extremely fair, caring and challenges you to see your full potential. If you have the opportunity to take a class with him, by all means do so.

very challenging, but rewarding class. pushes you to see your potential when it comes to understanding critical neurological concepts. the way he pushes you, through examinations, presentations and research papers is kind of scary. Don't know how I got through the class with a good mark but he is very fair if you put in the effort and you're smart.

Charles is an awesome guy but his tests are confusing. Good luck trying to predict whats going to be on the midterm. However, if you go get your exam remarked you might score some extra points. He is very friendly but will take 10 minutes to explain a question that you should be able to answer in one sentence on an exam, make sense, no!

KIN 446 is a great course and Charles is a great prof. The exams are very fair and he is a lenient marker. Having said that, the exams are on the harder side but if you listen to the recordings, you will do well because everything you need to know is explained well in lecture.

Smart prof who does very important work in the medical field. This course itself is very interesting and the presentations and essays are a great way of making the class more interesting. Loved the class! Lenient marker.

One of the most brilliant men I've ever met, but I guess you have to be to go the MD/PhD route. Unfortunately he's so smart he jumps from topic to topic in a way that I'm sure seems reasonable to him that can leave you scratching your head. His exams were very difficult, but this was balanced by the leniency he displayed in his marking.
